newsitem.title: USA: Philadelphia pension fund to sell Texaco stock.
newsitem.headline: Philadelphia pension fund to sell Texaco stock.

text.p: The board of Philadelphia's pension funds voted to divest $5.5 million worth of Texaco Inc. stock, citing tapes of alleged racial slurs by executives at the nation's third-largest oil company.
"People are very offended as to what was revealed on the Texaco tapes and we don't want to be part of that corporate culture," pension board Chairman Ben Hayllar said at the board's meeting.
The move comes a week after the Philadelphia City Council voted in a non-binding resolution to boycott Texaco and divest itself of all holdings in the oil company.
Pension board member Charles Johnson said the sale of the stock should send a message to other companies. "People are not to be taken for granted, especially minorities," he said.
The board is to review the move after a year to see if the oil company has made progress in minority hiring and promotions. It would then consider purchasing Texaco stock again.

Texaco last week reached a $176 million settlement of a 1994 lawsuit brought by a group of black employees accusing the company of systematically discriminating against blacks and denying them promotions. It was the biggest settlement of a discrimination case in the United States.
A former Texaco executive was charged on Tuesday with obstructing justice by destroying documents sought in the racial discrimination case.
White Plains, N.Y.-based Texaco, meanwhile, faces an ongoing consumer boycott due to the allegations of discrimination.
Texaco's stock lost 37.5 cents to $99.50 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
